text: Thomas Edison may have accidentally created graphene in 1879 while testing carbon-based bamboo filaments for light bulbs - 125 years before it was officially isolated in 2004.
Volvo gave away the patent for the three-point seat belt in 1962 for free - specifically to save lives rather than profit from the invention.
The tin can was patented in 1810 by Peter Durand, but the can opener wasn't patented until 1858 - for 48 years, people used chisels and hammers to open cans.

In 1888, a sensational story claimed that James Wickham, a British scientist, introduced two whales to the Great Salt Lake in an attempt to start a whale oil industry.
L'Attaque, the board game that became Stratego, was patented in 1908 by its designer, a 57-year-old woman (Hermance Edan).
Cecil Kent Drinker published his report on the Radium Girls only after a forged version was submitted in his name.
John S. McCain Sr. and John S. McCain Jr. were the first father-and-son pair to achieve the U.S. rank of four-star admiral.
A committee rejected six designs for the National Baseball Hall of Fame commemorative coins before approving a seventh, which was sketched during the meeting.
One 1886 night, 150 people broke into a courthouse and began moving it 15 miles (24 km), before getting stuck in a blizzard.
Ivan the Terrible (film) has been named as both one of the worst films and one of the greatest films of all time.
The inventor of the steamboat was an artist first.
The inventor of the telegraph was also a painter.
The inventor of the typewriter also invented carbon paper.
The inventor of the vacuum cleaner was inspired by hay fever.
The inventor of the hot dog bun was a cartoonist.
The inventor of instant coffee was Japanese.
The inventor of the zipper called it a clasp locker.
The inventor of the electric chair was a dentist.
The inventor of the diving suit was an artist.
The inventor of the bicycle was a German baron.
The inventor of the can opener invented it 48 years late.
The inventor of the chainsaw was a doctor.
The inventor of the bulldozer was an accountant.
The inventor of the ballpoint pen was a journalist.
The inventor of the ATM was a Scot.
The inventor of the barcode was inspired by Morse code.
The inventor of the elevator was a mechanic.
The inventor of air conditioning was a printer.
The inventor of the aspirin worked for Bayer.
The inventor of the jet engine was British.
The inventor of the microscope was Dutch.
The inventor of the telescope was also Dutch.
The inventor of the thermometer was Italian.
The inventor of the stethoscope was French.
The inventor of the compass was Chinese.
The inventor of paper was also Chinese.
The inventor of gunpowder was Chinese too.
The inventor of silk discovered it accidentally.
The inventor of ketchup was a doctor.
The inventor of graham crackers was a minister.
The inventor of corn flakes wanted to reduce desire.
The inventor of peanut butter was Canadian.
The inventor of the tea bag was American.
The inventor of the ice cream cone was Syrian.
The inventor of the popsicle was 11 years old.
The inventor of the chocolate bar was English.
The inventor of bubblegum was an accountant.
The inventor of the safety pin was American.
The inventor of the cotton candy was a dentist.
The inventor of the pencil eraser was English.
The inventor of the paperclip is disputed.
The inventor of the stapler was American.
The inventor of the rubber band was English.
The inventor of the push-pin was an architect.
The inventor of the binder clip was American.
The inventor of the sticky note was at 3M.
The inventor of the highlighter was Japanese.
The inventor of the marker was American.
The electric chair was invented by a dentist.
The inventor of the AK-47 regretted creating it.
The inventor of the telephone, Alexander Graham Bell, never called his wife or mother.
The Eiffel Tower shrinks 6 inches in winter.
The world's largest man-made structure is the Fresh Kills Landfill.
The world's longest sea bridge is in China at 34 miles.
The world's tallest structure is the Burj Khalifa at 2,717 feet.
The world's longest tunnel is the Gotthard Base Tunnel at 35 miles.
The world's deepest mine is Mponeng in South Africa at 2.5 miles.
The world's largest dam by volume is the Three Gorges Dam.
The Eiffel Tower can grow 6 inches in summer due to heat expansion.
The inventor of the microwave got the idea from a melted chocolate bar.
The first alarm clock could only ring at 4 AM because it was made for factory workers.
Bubble wrap was originally intended to be used as wallpaper, not packaging material.
The inventor of the Pringles can is buried in one — his ashes were placed in a Pringles container as he requested.
Play-Doh was originally invented as a wallpaper cleaner before being repurposed as a children's toy.
The chainsaw was originally invented to help with childbirth by cutting the pelvic bone during difficult deliveries.
WD-40 got its name because it was the result of the 40th attempt at creating a Water Displacement formula.
The microwave oven was invented by accident when a radar engineer noticed a chocolate bar in his pocket had melted.
Velcro was invented after the creator noticed how burrs stuck to his dog's fur during a walk.
The Eiffel Tower can grow up to 6 inches taller in summer due to thermal expansion of the iron.
Superglue was discovered accidentally twice — first in 1942 and again in 1951, both times while trying to make gun sights.
The inventor of the fire hydrant is unknown because the patent office where his records were stored burned down.
Teflon was discovered by accident when a chemist was trying to develop new refrigerants.
The patent for the fire escape was awarded to a man named Daniel Maseres in 1784, and it was essentially a rope attached to a basket.
Potato chips were invented in anger when a customer kept complaining that the fries were too thick.
The first commercially successful ballpoint pen was developed by a Hungarian journalist because fountain pens kept smudging his work.
Saccharin, the first artificial sweetener, was discovered when a chemist forgot to wash his hands before lunch.
The first vending machine was invented in ancient Egypt to dispense holy water in temples.
The yo-yo is one of the oldest toys in the world, with examples dating back to 500 BCE in Greece.
The can opener was invented 48 years after the can because early cans came with instructions to use a hammer and chisel.
Post-it Notes were invented by accident when a scientist at 3M was trying to create a super-strong adhesive.
The pacemaker was invented by accident when an engineer grabbed the wrong resistor while building a heart rhythm recorder.
X-rays were discovered when Wilhelm Röntgen noticed that a fluorescent screen was glowing despite being covered.
The slinky was invented by accident when a naval engineer dropped a tension spring and watched it walk down shelves.
Penicillin was discovered when Alexander Fleming noticed that mold had killed bacteria in a petri dish he'd accidentally left out.
The ice cream cone was invented at the 1904 World's Fair when an ice cream vendor ran out of dishes and a waffle vendor offered his wares.
Coca-Cola was originally marketed as a medicine to cure headaches and exhaustion.
Safety glass was discovered when a chemist noticed that a flask coated in plastic cellulose nitrate shattered but held together.
The inventor of the shopping cart initially hired fake shoppers to use them because customers thought they looked silly.
The match was invented 27 years after the lighter — lighters came first in 1823, matches in 1850.
Corn Flakes were invented by accident when the Kellogg brothers left cooked wheat to sit and it became flaky.
Viagra was originally developed to treat heart conditions — its other effect was discovered during clinical trials.
The wheelie suitcase wasn't invented until 1970, despite wheels and suitcases existing for centuries.
The inventor of the Super Soaker was a NASA engineer.
The creator of the Rubik's Cube took over a month to solve it himself.
Bubble wrap was originally invented to be wallpaper.
Play-Doh was originally a wallpaper cleaner.
The first alarm clock could only ring at 4 AM.
The inventor of the microwave oven noticed the candy bar in his pocket melted while working on radar.
The inventor of vaseline ate a spoonful every day.

The inventor of the skateboard used roller skate wheels.
The inventor of the printing press was a goldsmith.
The inventor of the parachute never tested it himself.
The inventor of the revolver was 18 years old.
The inventor of the phonograph was partially deaf.
The inventor of the saxophone was trying to improve the clarinet.
The inventor of corn flakes was against sugar.
The Eiffel Tower can grow up to 15 cm taller during summer due to thermal expansion of iron.
The Panama Canal uses a system of locks because the Pacific and Atlantic are at different heights.
